review.description:
This is probably my favorite Ethiopian restaurant, I love the food and the relax environment. This is the perfect place for a night out and the wine selection is just as delightful! 

Make sure you visit Bati if you enjoy international cuisine!
review.author: Eloah Nasir A.

review.description:
My boyfriend took me to this spot to start our "Alphabet Date" series, where we switch off and plan a date for each other for a letter of the alphabet. He wanted to start and A was for African food!

This place is a cute, cozy spot in Clinton Hill. It's great for a romantic date night with its dark tables and mood lighting. They only have beer and wine so we didn't drink but the options they had seemed good.

We ordered the Kategna for an app and the Meat Combo for Two for dinner, along with Baklava for dessert. 

Kategna- These were toasted triangles of injera brushed with berbere and kibe. They were nice and crunchy with the right amount of spice. 

Meat Combo- I really liked everything that was there- stewed lamb, beef, and we got the gomen as our veggie side. The injera was delicious and sopped up all the curries perfectly.

Baklava- Nice size piece that was warm and crunchy, yet soft and sweet.

Looking forward to my next visit!
review.author: Lincy J.

review.description: I give this place 4 stars because this is the 2nd Ethiopian restaurant that I have been to and I like this place much better. Ethiopian in Brooklyn is much better than DC Ethiopian in my opinion. The Ambience was nice, food good, the only problem was they didn't have ice for their ice water. Prices were typical for that area. Average $18-$22 per dish. Their injera was delicious the best I had so far. Nice slow cooked dishes.
review.author: Melissa H.

review.description: The ambiance is nice and cozy but service is not good. It took forever to not only place our order but to receive it as well. I had finished half a glass of wine by the time the order came out. The consistency of the veggie combo is very runny. The server wasn't friendly and they don't accept Amex.
review.author: Shivani S.

review.description: Stumbled upon this neighborhood in Clinton Hill off Fulton, it's a cute, romantic Ethiopian restaurant, great for a date night. I ordered the beef tibs, the gomen and the bebiere lentils with a glass of Cab. Great relaxing evening.
review.author: Alexandra C.

review.description: Tasty cuisine, for sure! The price is significantly higher than other Ethiopian restaurants in town and the portions are smaller. The staff also turned away a group that wanted to wait for a table, even though we were just getting ready to leave and they totally could have been seated where we were. As spices go, the food was flavorful but not particularly spicy... Not more than "mild" salsa. Great place to go with vegan friends!
review.author: Jane R.

review.description:
Ethiopian cuisine at its finest: slowly simmered stews, perfectly prepared njere and warm, friendly service makes this a can't miss spot. When my Ethiopian friend said this is her favorite restaurant, I knew we had to experience it. Her recommendation did not disappoint. The collard greens (gomen) and cabbage (tikil gomez) were not overcooked- a personal pet peeve - but weren't raw either. 

My Ethiopian favorite - especially on my plant based diet- is Missir Wett (berbere stewed split lentils) was amazing as well. 

Njere kept coming upon request and the staff were very accommodating. 

To get the most use of the space and bang for your buck- as well as get the most of the Ethiopian cultural experience- order the same thing for your whole party (not individual plates). They will allow you to add additional options if you need and it's the best way to go! It makes for a really fun dining experience as well!
review.author: Rasool B.

review.description:
It was a terrible.
The food was overpriced. The portions were small. The waiter was incredibly rude. After we paid, he kicked us out as we were getting together and trying to actually leave the restaurant.
review.author: Hardley J.

review.description:
Bati is good enough. Your standard Ethiopian dish selections (but no sambusas here). The portions are somewhat small for the price. A vegetarian combo for one, priced at 16 bucks gives you a spoonful of four dishes of your choice (lentils, split peas, collard greens etc) served on injera accompanied with One injera on the side. 

For some reason they price their mushroom dish (engudai tibs) separately ($18) and that can only be ordered with two dishes. All other Ethiopian restaurants I've visited include it in their veggie combo.

The food is good and their ater kik alicha (yellow split pea stew) is probably one of my favourites out of all the various Ethiopian restaurants throughout Brooklyn and Manhattan, but I always leave somewhat hungry. 

As far as ambiance, it's a small but nice space, dimly lit and good for a date or a few friends. They also serve my favourite St. George's lager which is always a plus.
review.author: Racquel B.

review.description: I was a bit skeptical after the 3.5 star reviews but really liked the place! Went on a Sunday evening, half full restaurant, decently speedy service. We got the tomato injera salad which had great flavor. The meat combination platter was a great way to try a few different types of wat.  As good as I remembered my favorite place in DC!
review.author: Fran W.

review.description: I love Ethiopian food and have tried a bunch of places. The quantity of the food that you get in the combo meal is just sooooo small. It absolutely does not make sense. My friend and I had to order more food and finished more than half of the two other entrees we got. The food is tasty but I would never come back. They're also very slow with bringing out the food. We had finished our respective glasses of wine by the time the food came out.
review.author: Harshini R.

review.description:
At first glance Bati seems truly inviting. The environment is small and cozy and appears to be well maintained. Upon arrival we were not greeted at the door but behind a counter towards the back. The gentleman telling us to sit wherever. 
Myself and two other friends sat to enjoy a shared Vegan Combination platter, which was ok until we found multiple pieces of hard plastic (Polystyrene) in our food. When brought to the waiter's attention, he asked us what it was as if he did not know then took the pieces in a napkin to the kitchen. When he returned he mentioned the kitchen stated a storage container previously broke so that is where the pieces came from. The waiter then preceded to walk away and did not accommodate us or apologize. The bill arrived with all the charges, including the food we did not finish because we were afraid it had more pieces contaminating it. 
We asked the waiter what he could do for the inconvenience and he mentioned at first nothing and then proceeded not to apologize once again. We asked to speak to the manager but he then stated he was the manager. You can clearly see where this story is going.
Long story short Brooklyn has too many restaurants. Don't eat at Bati to receive contaminated food and horrible service.
review.author: Tuso B.

review.description:
Bati
NY BK Fort Greene
8pm Wednesday 26th July 2017
Three Stars


The food and atmosphere was great but the service was rather sub-par.  The wait staff was not very attentive. It took a long time to take our order. It took a long time for her to get us a bottle of mead. I watched the waiter sit and talk for 5 minutes before even attempting to get the bottle. After a bit of misunderstanding with our order, we got our food.  Everything was great.  The portions look small but end up being really filling after eating a bunch of Injera (Ethiopian Flatbread).
review.author: Leonard L.

review.description: The meat platter was good, I was there last night excited for the meat platter. Then the waiter gave us a vegan platter instead. I was with a friend having a conversation so we didn't see before we started digging in only to realize it is vegan. We wanted them to change it but they refused to cuz we already touched the food. The waiter was like "YOU CANT TELL ITS NOT MEAT BEFORE EATING IT???" Like it's our fault that we ate the wrong food, when it's their job to give the right food.... I'm allergic to some kinds of beans and I don't eat vegetables, so I had to sit through and watch my partner stuffing vegan food down her throat cuz she doesn't like to waste food. Most miserable dinner I ever had.
review.author: ZhongJei L.

review.description: I picked up my meal and ate at home. The vegetarian combo costs like $18, which is too much. However, it was one of the tastiest Ethiopian meals I've ever had. I had the lentils, chickpeas and collard greens. The flavor was amazing (and not spicy). However, the consistency is very runny, so it's actually hard to eat with the injera without dripping all over the place. That's the only negative.
review.author: Kat D.

review.description: Love to come here for Kitfo and mushroom Tibs. Appreciate the post-kitsch modernized decor, always nice to see Habesha food rise above the "destination dining" bar. Excellent staff. Real Ethiopian food instead of "ferengi" or foreigner style. Tables are wobbly but all is forgiven when food comes.
review.author: Khadijah Lucero J.

review.description: We had a wonderful meal at Bati this Saturday afternoon. The vibe is laid-back with great Ethiopian food. It gets busy in the evenings, but it's very relaxed in the afternoon with open and airy windows--very similar to a restaurant you might find in Addis.
review.author: Adam S.

review.description:
Delivery review follows:

I love tibs. Sadly living in Silver Spring exposed me to the best Ethiopian community in the country, as well as their amazing food. I know tibs can be good and spicy. Twice now the tibs from Bati have been overcooked and lacking flavor. It's sad. I really wish this would be great as I enjoy that I get two vegetables with the protein. But if the tibs aren't great then the experience is ruined. I likely am done ordering from here.
review.author: David M.

review.description: Quite nice overall. The stews were reasonably tasty and our server was great. I found the injera to be on the thick side. What really, really impressed me was an appetizer called kategna, made from toasted triangles of injera brushed with berbere and kibe. It was an amazing treat. I could eat kategna for days!
review.author: Laura W.

review.description:
The is the second time in a couple of weeks that I've tested the validity of a yelp three star rating and the second time I wish I hadn't. I've had Ethiopian cuisine before and while there was nothing extremely wrong, the fare seemed quite bland and flavorless. 

I had the mixed meat platter and to drink I had the honey wine. I liked the honey wine but the meat on the mixed meat platter didn't taste fresh or tender. The injera was a. It too sour for my liking.

The service and ambience was okay, the lighting was quite poor. l'm not sure if that is intentional to create some sort of ambience, but is was a little hard to see what you are eating.

I doubt I'll visit here again.
review.author: Subodh M.
